Before I leave the general area of crime in so far as it relates to this Bill I want to refer to one remark made by Deputy Woods. He contended that there is an essential contradiction in the position of the Minister for Justice when he says, on the one hand, that the level of crime is falling and, on the other, that the level of malicious injuries compensation is going up. I would point out to Deputies that there is a three year limitation period in which the proceedings for compensation for malicious damage must be commenced. There can, therefore, be a delay of up to three years in processing claims and, as a result, there would always be a timelag between a fall off in crime and a reduction in the claims for compensation.

I now turn to the question of insurance. The only public pronouncement which has been made by the insurance industry in relation to this Bill of which I am aware is the statement reported in The Irish Press of 30 January 1986 by a spokesman for one of the insurance companies who said that, while the measure would have an effect on premiums, he did not expect a dramatic increase. For Deputies to suggest that there will be a dramatic and widespread increase in insurance premiums solely as a result of this Bill is wild exaggeration. Owners of certain properties, particularly in urban areas, will obviously be affected to some degree. However, the cost of insurance for the average citizen is unlikely to be greatly affected whether it is in respect of his house or motor car, by this Bill. Deputy Woods alleged, and I quote——
The Minister is in cloud cuckooland.
The Deputy had his time. I quote:
...the Minister's proposals will directly cause motor and motor cycle insurance premiums to rocket upwards....

MainHeading.P: I have to point out that it is in limited circumstances only — for example, where a car is stolen and then recovered damaged — that substantial claims arise in respect of motor vehicles. The number and cost of claims of this nature is small compared with the number and cost of motor insurance claims in respect of accidental damage and personal injury. Any increase in car insurance premiums as a result of this Bill should therefore be negligible.

I have another reason for saying this. The present position whereby compensation is payable under the malicious injuries scheme without the need to prove malicious intent, where a car is taken and recovered crashed, is a result of a Supreme Court decision handed down in June 1984 on the interpretation of the 1981 Malicious Injuries Act. Commenting on that decision a spokesman for the Irish Insurance Association was reported in The Irish Press of 8 June 1984 to have said that he would be slow to say that costs would actually go down for motorists as a result of the decision because such cases were not major items in terms of overall motor insurance costs but that it should certainly serve to help contain the costs at least. Now that the position as affects such claims is, in effect, being reversed I would expect that insurance companies would be equally slow to consider raising premiums on account of what, in relation to the more costly claims affecting cars under the malicious injuries scheme, is a return to the pre-1981 position.

Both Deputies Woods and Hyland claimed that about 50 per cent of the amount of compensation paid out under the malicious injuries scheme relates to damage to cars and motorcycles. There is no statistical evidence to back up that claim. In fact there is no evidence that the cost of malicious damage claims in relation to cars and motorcycles constitutes a major element in the overall cost of malicious damage compensation.

Speaker.P: The Minister will find out if she asks the insurance companies how much they are collecting.

Deputy Woods referred to figures contained in a survey carried out by Dublin Corporation. I understand that in 1985 Dublin Corporation prepared an estimated breakdown of malicious injuries claims for their area. That suggested that 48 per cent of the number of claims in 1984 was for damage to cars and motorcycles. I should have reservations even in quoting that figure as its statistical base could be called into question. But there is no basis whatsoever for suggesting that because 48 per cent of the number of claims related to motorcars and cycles that 48 per cent of the amount of compensation paid out was in respect of these vehicles. Dublin Corporation do not keep statistics of the cost of claims broken down so as to give the cost in relation to motor cars. But a statistical exercise carried out in Sligo revealed that in 1983, while 39 per cent of the number of claims related to motor vehicles, they account for 5 per cent only of the total amount of compensation claimed.

This makes a nonsense of Second Stage debate. This is nonsense. This is not a reply to a debate.

It has been suggested by Deputy Woods that the Bill should be amended so that persons who cannot get insurance at a reasonable rate——
This is not a reply——
——should be entitled to compensation from the State under the malicious injuries scheme.
A Cheann Comhairle——

A Cheann Comhairle we are grown, mature parliamentarians——

The Minister has shown a total disregard for the importance of law and order and crime especially in Dublin, Cork and Limerick——

The Minister is not even here. Where is he?

This is ridiculous.

In effect what the Deputy is suggesting as a general principle is that the insurance companies and not the Government should decide whether damage should be compensatable by the State. That would be a totally unacceptable position for any Government to adopt. What the Government have decided is to limit compensation to those cases where traditionally insurance cover has not normally been available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. V. Brady Mr. V. Brady
Speaker.P: On a point of order, a Cheann Comhairle, our most recent speakers this evening made some very relevant points in this debate——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick

Speaker.hpid: Mr. V. Brady Mr. V. Brady

Speaker.hpid: Mr. V. Brady Mr. V. Brady
Speaker.P: Might I just say that Deputy Cowen made some very valid points in his contribution this evening. Obviously, the Minister's speech was prepared in advance which affords no opportunity to reply.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I cannot compose the Minister's reply. The Chair cannot do that.
Who has composed it? The Minister is not here to stand over his reply.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Minister without interruption.

A number of Deputies on both sides of the House said that as a result of this legislation businesses may have problems in obtaining malicious damage cover in particular areas and suggested that specific provision be made for such cases. This problem already exists in relation to other forms of insurance cover — for example, theft and fire insurance — and the enactment of this Bill will not dramatically alter the situation. I understand that in some instances the reluctance of insurers to provide cover may relate to the fact that one is dealing with old buildings which may be fire hazards due to the material used in construction, lack of sprinkler systems, faulty electrical wiring and such like. This is not to deny that a real problem may exist. We have listened to the Deputies on this point and recognise their concern. It is, however, primarily an insurance matter. The Minister for Justice is taking it up with his colleague, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, to see if anything can be done to deal with any possible vacuum that might result from the passing of this Bill.

Deputy Woods has been very liberal in his use of quotations from sources in the insurance industry to provide precise figures for increases in insurance rates arising from this Bill. The prime motive behind any private sector firm, including those in the insurance sector, is to make a profit. They are of course, perfectly entitled to put forward their views on any legislation that might affect them. However, because the insurance industry have a particular interest in the matter they cannot be regarded as being entirely neutral. As a result any views they put forward on the likely increase in insurance premiums as a result of this Bill have to be viewed in that light. The Deputy quoted pending increases of 45 per cent in primary school insurance premiums and 30 per cent in the case of post primary schools. I am not going to comment on those figures. However, I would point out that insurance premiums charged to schools cover many other risks apart from malicious damage — for example, public liability, the pupils, staff, indemnity of staff and board members and school buildings.

MainHeading.P: I understand that the existing level of primiums is likely to be increased, partly because of anticipated increased costs for insurers arising from this Bill, but also because extended cover is to be provided in the area of public liability and indemnity. These increases will, of course, be subject to the normal consultation process between the insurance industry and the Department of Industry and Commerce.

As to the particular matter of damage caused to school buildings through vandalism the Ministers for Education and Justice are fully conscious of the problems facing schools in this area. The question was the subject of discussions between officials of the Department of Justice and officials of the Department of Education. As Deputy Woods and other Deputies rightly pointed out, schools in certain areas face particular problems. I understand that the Department of Education are working closely with those schools in order to improve security by such measures as the installation of unbreakable glass and better fencing.

Deputy Leonard and Deputy O'Hanlon raised the question of certain damage caused maliciously to local authority property which does not come within the scope of the Malicious Injuries Scheme. The Minister for Justice is having consultations about this matter with the Minister for the Environment. What is essentially at issue here is the way in which the cost of repairing such damage should be met. This may well be a matter that might be more appropriately considered in the context of the general funding of local authorities but, as I have said, the Minister for Justice is in consultation with the Minister for the Environment on the question.

Deputy Leonard also asked about providing some kind of appeal mechanism if a certificate is refused by a chief superintendent. The example he quoted relates to a non-statutory scheme under which the Government reimburse local authorities the full cost of compensation awarded agains them for damage caused by the use of explosives and relating to the disturbances in Northern Ireland. As, under the new scheme, the full cost of all awards will be met by the Exchequer, that particular scheme will terminate once the Bill comes into effect. There will then be a statutory scheme in its place and the question whether an organisation of the type mentioned in section 2 of the Bill was involved will, in the event of a dispute on the issue, be decided upon by the courts. Provision of a certificate by a chief superintendent is intended to help the applicant prove that such an organisation was involved. If the chief superintendent refuses to give a certificate it will be open to the applicant to use other evidence to prove to the court that such an organisation was involved. In the light of that there does not seem to be a need for any further appeal mechanism.

Deputy Kelly's point in relation to section 8 of the Bill will be considered before Committee Stage but it may be said at this juncture that section 8 is continuing the same basic provision that exists in section 22 of the 1981 Act which as far as I am aware has not given rise to any particular difficulties.

Deputy Flynn also mentioned that no special provision was being made in relation to agricultural property. There is no particular problem in obtaining insurance cover for agricultural property. Many companies provide insurance in this area, including the Farmers' Business Development Insurance Company established by the Irish Farmers' Association in 1970. In addition, disputes which might involve malicious damage are no longer a common feature.

Deputy Flynn referred to the fact that in England there was compensation available for malicious damage in certain circumstances. In fact, in England compensation for malicious damage is available only when the damage results from disorder caused by riot. No compensation is available from public funds in respect of damage caused in any other circumstances. This has been the position in England since the last century.

Deputy Skelly spoke about abuse in relation to claims for malicious damage under the existing schemes. He said that if this problem were dealt with the level of claims would be reduced. The fact is that in the final analysis it is a matter for the courts to decide whether a claim is well founded or not. The claimant must prove his case to the satisfaction of the court. Of course, the matter might not go to court if the local authority is in no doubt that the damage was caused maliciously.

Deputy Cowen claimed that it is not possible to claim compensation for malicious damage unless those who caused the damage are unknown. This is not correct. It may be that in many cases the actual perpetrators will be unknown but this is not a condition for claiming compensation.

In conclusion, I would again make the point that what the Government are doing here is transferring an existing charge on the public purse — in other words the general taxpayer — to where it essentially belongs. The Government see no reason why the ordinary taxpayer in Ireland should any longer be subject to a greater burden in this respect than his counterpart in other countries.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Report of Commission on Social Welfare.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if the Government accepts the recommendations of the Report of the Commission on Social Welfare; if so, when the recommendations will be implemented; when the report will be made available to the public; if it will be debated in the Dáil; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
asked the Minister for Social Welfare if she intends making the Report of the Commission on Social Welfare available before the summer recess of Dáil Éireann; and, if not, the reason.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 15 and 16 together.

The Report of the Commission on Social Welfare was laid before both Houses of the Oireachtas on 11 June 1986 providing Deputies and Senators with the opportunity of examining the contents of the report before publication.

The report is currently being printed and I expect that copies will be available for circulation to all members of the Oireachtas by mid-July. At the same time, the report will be made available to the public generally.

The level of additional social welfare expenditure to finance all of the commission's proposals, over £560 million in 1985 terms, prevents full immediate implementation of the recommendations. Nonetheless, the Government will be examining ways in which improvements to the system can be made within the overall financial constraints which exist. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Department of Social Welfare Computerisation Programme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reasons for, and the background to, her decision to award contracts for up to 200 VDU's from two foreign sources, when Irish companies could just as satisfactorily meet her needs.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department is at present implementing a major programme of computerisation aimed at improved levels of service to the public while at the same time developing additional safeguards and fraud control features. Part of this programme involves increasing the number of visual display units — VDU's — from 600 to 800 during 1986. While many of these will be used in the headquarters buildings in Dublin, some will be installed in employment exchanges and information offices around the country to provide quick access to claim information for claimants.

In view of the critical nature of the Department's systems and the expansion of the country-wide network, other factors, in addition to cost and origin of the VDU's, had to be carefully considered. Products of proven reliability capable of being maintained on a countrywide basis were required. The Department is satisfied that the products chosen best met the various criteria.
The normal tendering procedures were followed. All the companies invited to tender have bases in Ireland and in fact both successful companies are substantial employers in this country.

asked the Minister for Social Welfare if she is satisfied with the forms of child income support presently available to families and the steps she intends to take in the future to improve this very important form of family support.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: As announced in the National Plan Building on Reality 1985-1987 the Government have decided to rationalise the existing child support system through the introduction of a new child benefit scheme which would unify in a single payment State support towards the cost of rearing children. The new payment would be paid directly to the mother and would be treated as part of taxable income for the taxpayer in the family.

As a first step, the Government decided to introduce, with effect from April 1986, a non-taxable child benefit scheme. Under this scheme a monthly child benefit of £15.05 is paid for each of the first five children and a monthly payment of £21.75 is paid for the sixth and subsequent child.

It is intended to introduce the fully taxable child benefit scheme as soon as it is possible to do so. There are still a number of administrative and technical problems associated with this part of the proposal and these are at present under consideration by my Department.
The Commission on Social Welfare have made a number of recommendations on family income support and I will be taking these into account in future developments in this area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Department of Social Welfare Management Review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if a management review of her Department will take place as recommended by the Public Accounts Committee.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: In accordance with Government policy as set out in the White Paper Serving the Country Better the management systems of my Department are being reviewed.

MainHeading.P: A first significant step in this direction was taken late last year when my Department was reorganised along the lines set out in the White Paper. The reorganisation of the Department involves the structuring of the Department into two separate areas. One area headed by the secretary is responsible for advising the Minister on policy matters. The other, known as the social welfare services office, deals with purely executive work and is responsible for the day-to-day running of the schemes and services of my Department. The main objective of this new approach is to enable those concerned with the operation of the various schemes to concentrate more fully on effective management and the provision of an efficient and speedy delivery of services.

This restructuring is a major step in the programme of modernisation of my Department's services which has been underway for some time and which has been largely based on the extension of the latest computer technology into practically all areas of the Department's business. The various other measures proposed in the Government's White Paper will be implemented as soon as possible. In addition to the foregoing the Department is at present in the process of engaging expert consultant assistance to undertake a review of systems with particular reference to the unemployment payments area in view of the publicity given in recent months to incidences of fraud.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - “Birmingham Six” Court Case Review.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, arising from his replies to Parliamentary Questions Nos. 6 and 14 of 12 March 1986, whether a decision has now been received at British Home Office level on whether there are sufficient grounds to warrant referring the cases of the Birmingham Six to the Court of Appeal there; and whether he will make a statement on the up-to-date situation in the light of progress or otherwise at that level.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry):
Speaker.P: I am advised that the review of the case of the six men who were convicted in 1975 for offences in connection with the bombing of two public houses in Birmingham is still under consideration by the British Home Secretary, Mr. Douglas Hurd.

I recently received a reply from Mr. Hurd to the representations I had made in which he stated that he was carefully considering the points which were raised in the “World in Action” television programme on 28 October 1985, and that consideration of that aspect of the case was almost complete. I hope that the Home Secretary will decide in favour of referring these cases to the Court of Appeal and I will be keeping myself informed of developments.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Trade with South Africa.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will make a statement on the extent of our trading relationship with South Africa, in particular, if he will give a breakdown of the major items imported from and exported to that country; and if he will give an indication of the likely effects on the Irish economy of possible trade sanctions by this country against South Africa.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Noonan,
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Total trade between Ireland and South Africa has grown from £22.726 million in 1980 to £49.956 million in 1985. Exports in 1985 amounted to £29.551 million ranking South Africa as our 27th export market in that year. Imports from South Africa in 1985 amounted to £20.405 million giving Ireland therefore a trade surplus of £9.145 million

Our principle exports by classification in 1985 to South Africa were organic chemicals, office machines and ADP equipment, medicinal and pharmaceutical products, industrial machinery and miscellaneous edible products.
Our main imports by classification from South Africa in 1985 were fruit and vegetables, coal, coke and briquettes, fertilisers, textiles and iron and steel.

The Department of Agriculture will be the licensing agency. It is not possible to quantify the exact effects which these restrictions will have but given past consumption it is obvious that similar products must be sought elsewhere.

The South Africans have already made demarches to countries including Ireland which have taken sanctions against them. It is, therefore not unlikely that there will be exchanges under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Laois County Council Outdoor Staff.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if, in view of his commitment to the full time employment of county council outdoor staff, he will now make sufficient funds available to Laois County Council to keep on workers in full time employment, and to carry out essential repairs to county roads which in many areas have totally disintegrated.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Boland) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Boland)
Speaker.P: It has been the practice, as established by successive Governments, that local authorities carry full responsibility for the maintenance of county roads and road grants have not, therefore, been provided for this purpose. I am aware, however, that the condition of county roads is a matter of serious concern in a number of areas and that some county councils are experiencing difficulties in financing necessary works to these roads. As I stated in my reply to Questions Nos. 3 and 19 on 10 June 1986, I have asked my Department to examine the overall position urgently in the light of this situation and I expect to be in a position to make an announcement about the matter in the near future.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Kavanagh):
Speaker.P: The canals are owned by CIE but will be transferred to OPW on 1 July 1986.

asked the Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry if he is aware that a series of trawlers were fishing illegally in Dingle Bay last week in violation of the law and that this is a regular occurrence; and if he will state the proposals, if any, he has in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Kavanagh):
Speaker.P: I am well aware that illegal salmon fishing takes place at various points around our coast and the relevant regional fisheries boards are doing everything possible with the resources available to them to cope with the situation. In addition I have arranged for special patrols by the Navy. Unfortunately many of the people engaged in such illegal activities when challenged violently resist the efforts of fishery officers in carrying out their duties. I must stress that the various protection regulations on salmon fishing are designed to conserve salmon stocks and to provide an equitable share of the salmon catch for the different categories of fishermen involved. I cannot condone breaches of the law or the violent behaviour of some offenders which places staff engaged on fishery protection work at serious risk. My aim is to enforce the necessary conservation measures in as fair and equitable a manner as possible in the interests of the future of the fishery.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - River Slaney Salmon Stocks.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry the action he proposes to take in order to rectify the serious damage which has been caused to salmon stocks on the River Slaney, up-stream of Clohamon Weir; his views on the fish pass, designed and constructed by his Department at this location proving to be utterly and totally unsatisfactory; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Kavanagh):
Speaker.P: I have no firm evidence that serious damage has been caused to salmon stocks on the River Slaney up-stream of Clohamon Weir. However, in deference to representations made to me by various angling interests I have arranged that scentists from my Department will carry out a survey of the area shortly with a view to establishing if fish are being held up at the weir and, if so, the reasons therefore and what remedial action needs to be taken.

The fish pass in the weir was constructed by the Eastern Regional Fisheries Board in 1984 and designed by my Department. A counter was installed in the pass in January 1985 and it recorded 2,600 salmon moving up-stream through the fish pass in that year. It appears that the counter and pass were working satisfactorily at that time.

Tá glactha ag an Stát mar chúram air féin go gcothabhálfar Príosún Chill Mhaighneann go deo mar mhúsaem staire agus go gceadófar don phobal dul isteach ann sa mhéid chéanna, ar a laghad, a cheadaítear i gcás Ospidéal Ríoga Chill Mhaighneann.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: I am aware of the Midland Health Board's proposal to close two wards for elderly or psycho-geriatric patients, at St. Fintan's Hospital, Portlaoise this year. This will be facilitated by the board's success in being able to discharge some patients to more suitable accommodation in the community and to transfer others to more appropriate geriatric institutional care in the area. The relocation of patients to facilities, especially community based facilities, which more appropriately meet their particular needs is clearly in line with the recommendations of the report Psychiatric Services — Planning for the Future published last year. It is also in line with the Midland Health Board's own plans to decentralise services currently provided in their psychiatric hospitals, including St. Fintan's to locally based psychiatric teams.

The development of the kind of community orientated psychiatric service recommended in Psychiatric Services — Planning for the Future, and now widely accepted as the best way of treating most mental illness, will inevitably mean a continuation of the already well established trend towards a diminishing role for the psychiatric hospital, and its centralised institutional style of providing care.

asked the Minister for Health the way in which he envisages accommodating the community psychiatric services in the health board areas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: Guidelines on the development of a community psychiatric service are set out in detail in the report Psychiatric Services — Planning for the Future published last year. The overall objective of such a service is to ensure that as many people as possible receive treatment in their normal social environment, thus avoiding the need for admission to hospital. The achievement of this objective will necessitate the development at local level of a range of facilities including day hospitals, day centres, hostels, sheltered accommodation and work shops, retraining centres etc. The report recommends that these services should be organised around multidisciplinary psychiatric teams, each serving specifically defined geographic areas.

This process of implementing this policy has already begun with the preparation by each health board of a detailed plan as to how they envisage this type of service being developed in each of their respective areas. These plans are currently being examined in my Department.
asked the Minister for Health the provisions which are envisaged for the care of adult mentally handicapped within the context of the community services.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The main principle underlying the provision of mental handicap services is to ensure that people with a mental handicap, both adults and children, should enjoy life that is as normal as possible in close association with their families and friends. The services which are provided for adults and which are being further developed are aimed at supporting this principle. These services include: Continuing Assessment Services; Day Care Units; Vocational and Long-term Training Centres; Residential Services.

Residential services include a number of different levels of residential care, ranging from unsupervised domestic scale houses with as few as three or four persons to institutions providing centralised services for persons with severe levels of handicap.

I have recently set up a consultative group to help me develop guidelines for the mental handicap services. This group will report to me after consultations with persons and organisations providing services for mentally handicapped people.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Rehabilitation of the Physically Handicapped.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will give a list of the programmes which are in place to rehabilitate the physically handicapped.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The Deputy will appreciate that because of the very wide range of services available for the rehabilitation of physically handicapped people which cover a number of Government Departments and agencies it would not be possible to detail these services in this reply.

In so far as my Department is concerned the rehabilitation services include medical rehabilitation, vocational assessment, guidance and placement services, income maintenance and training allowances, domiciliary care, the provision of aids and appliances, occupational therapy and day care services. The services for the disabled are however outlined in considerable detail in the Government's Green Paper on Services for Disabled People, Towards a Full Life. I am arranging to send the Deputy a copy of the paper under separate cover.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Support Programmes for Alcoholics.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the current situation in relation to the provision of support programmes for alcoholics; and what is envisaged by him for the future under the community type service programme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: Treatment programmes for alcoholism are now provided by the psychiatric hospitals as well as at a number of centres specialising in alcoholism such as the Rutland Centre in Templeogue and the Hanley Centre in Dún Laoghaire. Support is also provided at the many branches of Alcoholics Anonymous throughout the country, often in association with Alanon and Alateen centres for the families of persons with alcohol related problems.

MainHeading.P: In recent years there has been a definite movement away from institutional care for persons with alcohol-related problems, and a growing tendency to treat alcoholism on an out-patient basis. The report Psychiatric Services — Planning for the Future published last year, which sets guidelines for the development of the psychiatric services, recommends that in future, the approach to alcohol-related problems should be based more on prevention than on treatment and that the service should be community based with major emphasis on out-patient treatment.

Health boards are now drawing up their plans for comprehensive psychiatric services and it is intended that local alcoholism services, in accordance with the guidelines set down in the report will be included as part of this service.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the current position in relation to the establishment of maternity committees as envisaged in The Maternity and Infant Care Review.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The establishment of maternity commitees on a pilot basis is currently under consideration.

As you are aware, the public health nurse has a major caring and advisory role to play in the ante and post natal periods. Before a final decision as to the committees' terms of reference and composition can be made it is considered appropriate to await the outcome of the review of public health nursing which will, inter alia, address itself to the problem of linking community and institutional nursing services.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Oncology Screening for Women.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the present position in relation to the availability of oncology screening for women.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The question of providing oncology screening for women is a broad issue with not only major resource implications but questions at issue relative to the efficacy of such an approach to detection. The matter is, of course, kept under constant review in the light of developments here and in other countries.
At present cervical smear tests are available from general practitioners as well as from health centres and hospital outpatients departments.

The three main forms of breast examination are mammography, clinical examination and self examination and their relative places in the early detection of cancer is also still the subject of debate. General practitioners or public health nurses will advise on breast self examinations and the general practitioners will conduct a clinical examination and may then refer the patient to a specialist centre for further examinations which may include mammography.
asked the Minister for Health the amount of money which is being provided in the current year for community psychiatric services.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: At present the total cost of the psychiatric service is not apportioned between community and institutional services as separate accounts are not kept in relation to the community element of the service.

The overall expenditure in the current year on the psychiatric service is estimated at £157.5 million. The services being provided in the community include nursing services, out-patient clinics, day hospitals, day centres, hostels and sheltered workshops.

MainHeading.P: To date submissions have been received from 26 organisations and individuals. It is hoped that all the bodies circulated will submit comments by the end of July at the latest with a view to processing these by the end of autumn 1986.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Geriatric Assessment Services.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the present position regarding the provision of geriatric assessment services.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: In the development of institutional services for the elderly more emphasis is being placed on proper assessment so that the needs of the patient are indentified at an early stage and steps taken to meet these needs. The general approach to providing an assessment service is to have a geriatric assessment unit as a specialised department in a general hospital with a physician in geriatric medicine as the consultant in charge of the unit. The planning of all new general hospitals contains provision for geriatric assessment units. In a number of hospitals geriatric assessment services are under the direction of a general physician or a general practitioner with a special interest in the elderly. Geriatric assessment services are currently provided at the following hospitals:
St. Vincent's Hospital, Dublin;
St. James's Hospital, Dublin;
James Connolly Memorial Hospital, Dublin;
St. Laurence's Hospital, Dublin;
St. Mary's Hospital, Dublin;
St. Finbarr's Hospital, Cork;
Merlin Park Hospital, Galway;
Castlebar General Hospital;
Sacred Heart Home, Castlebar;
Sligo General Hospital;
St. Patrick's Hospital, Cashel;
St. Columba's Hospital, Thomastown;
St. John's Hospital, Enniscorthy.

MainHeading.P: Plans are currently in preparation for the establishment of geriatric assessment facilities in the Mid-Western and North-Eastern Health Board areas and for the improvement of these services in the South-Eastern and Southern Health Board areas.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Insurance of Fostered Children.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health his views on the difficulty that exists for foster parents in so far as the question of suitable general insurance is concerned to cover children in their care and the difficulties that could arise from possible claims against foster parents for accidents or negligence which might arise while these children are in their care; if he will make arrangements to extend the health boards' ordinary general insurance cover to deal with all children in care under the control of these health boards; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: I am very concerned at statements which have been made recently in the media and elsewhere suggesting that foster parents could find themselves having to pay compensation to natural parents in the event of injuries occurring to foster children in their care.

These statements have alarmed many foster parents and caused much anxiety to social workers and others in health boards who are striving to develop foster care as an alternative to residential care for children. Apart from any other consideration, fears of this nature are not conductive to foster parents treating foster children as integral members of their families.

I am advised that no claim by a natural parent against a foster parent in respect of injuries to a foster child would succeed unless the foster parent was either directly responsible for the injury or had contributed to it by being negligent in not looking after the child properly.

MainHeading.P: It seems to me, therefore, that the overwhelming majority of foster parents who are doing their best to look after foster children as they would care for children of their own have absolutely no reason to fear. The only situation where a foster parent would have reason to fear is where he or she had caused or contributed to a child's injury. I am sure the Deputy will agree that it would neither be proper nor desirable for a health board to shield such persons by providing some form of indemnity to foster parents, irrespective of responsibility for the injury.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Appointment of Anaesthetists.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: Additional anaesthetists are appointed by employing authorities in line with the statutory provisions and other procedures required prior to the making of such appointments. These processes include a requirement that my Department will give its observations on the financial implications before an application is made to Comhairle na nOspidéal for approval to a consultant post. Comhairle na nOspidéal is the statutory body set up under the Health Act, 1970 to regulate the number and type of appointments of consultant medical staff.
At present the following proposals for additional appointments in the North-Eastern Health Board are being processed:—

One post in Louth County Hospital in respect of which observations on the financial implications of approving the additional post have recently been issued by my Department. Approval for this post is now a matter for Comhairle na nOspidéal.

A proposal to create a post at Cavan General Hospital was recently submitted by the North-Eastern Health Board. This is currently being processed and the observations on the financial implications of approving the post will be issued in the near future.

MainHeading.P: A proposal in respect of an additional post at Monaghan General Hospital was received from the health board some time ago. About £¼ million would be required to fund this post and this is being examined at present.
The following table sets out the number of anaesthetists appointed and the board areas to which they were appointed during 1984 and 1985.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - South-Eastern Health Board Expenditure.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Treacy Mr. S. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the expected deficit in relation to money allocated to the South-Eastern Health Board; its expected spending requirements for the current year; the way in which it is expected that the health board will make up the deficit; if it is likely that the deficit will lead to cutbacks in services in the area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: I have approved of spending levels for health boards and other health agencies for 1986 to the maximum extent possible within the resources at my disposal. In accordance with section 31 of the Health Act, 1970, health boards have a statutory obligation to avoid exceeding the approved spending level.

The South-Eastern Health Board's decisions in relation to the 1986 budgetary arrangements included an objective not to exceed their 1986 budget allocation of £96.54 million. The measures which have been approved by the board towards the realisation of the targetted reductions include reductions in payroll costs including reductions in locum costs and payroll extras, and in travelling expenses and energy costs. It is understood that further measures to achieve cost reductions are being considered.

MainHeading.P: I am satisfied that the resources at the health board's disposal are sufficient to enable essential services to be maintained.

MainHeading.RHead: Differentation in Urban and Rural Areas
MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Differentation in Urban and Rural Areas.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if she is satisfied with the present policy of (a) paying different rates of unemployment assistance to persons in urban and rural areas and (b) the provision of fuel vouchers only to those in urban areas; and, if not, the proposals she has to eliminate these anomalies.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The payment of higher rates of unemployment assistance in certain urban areas than in other areas has always been a feature of the unemployment assistance scheme. It can be argued that in principle the same rates of assistance should apply in all areas. However the establishment of a unified rate of assistance would have financial implications and would be a matter for consideration in a budgetary context.

The existence of separate fuel schemes in certain urban areas with different conditions of entitlement from those which apply under the national fuel scheme administered by the health boards is not a satisfactory situation. The possibility of effecting a rationalisation of the fuel schemes is being examined.

My Department has not been offered an adequate explanation for the delays which have occurred in this case and will take every step open to it to ensure that the school will be ready for occupation by the beginning of the new school-year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: Following appeals against the original allocations approved by my Department a number of the colleges in question were given revised teacher allocations under agreed report 5/82.

Moreover, the teacher allocations for these colleges are examined on an annual basis in order to determine teacher requirements for the ensuing academic year. This examination takes into account such factors as new courses, course development, increased student numbers and increased accommodation. On that basis a number of additional lecturer I and lecturer II posts have been allocated from year to year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Cork School Contract.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he is aware that a firm (details supplied) in County Cork have been or are about to be given the contract by the Office of Public Works for the erection of a school in County Cork, that this company is in breach of section 10 of the Industrial Relations Act, 1969, arising from an agreement of 7 March 1969 between the CIF and the AS Woodworkers under which they are obliged to become members of the CIF pension scheme and that this company have failed to carry out the terms of the Labour Court recommendations D84/1633; and if he will withhold this and any other contracts with this company until they have honoured these arrangements and their legal obligations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department has entered into a contract with the firm referred to by the Deputy for the erection of a school at Union Hall, County Cork. Tenders for the project were invited by the Office of Public Works. In the process of dealing with the matter, that office received assurances from the firm that it was registered in respect of the pension scheme referred to. The formal contract subsequently entered into with the firm by my Department contains a standard clause to the effect that.

...the Contractor shall pay rates of wages and observe hours of labour and conditions of employment not less favourable than those laid down by the National Joint Industrial Council for the Construction Industry.
This clause is taken to encompass an obligation on the firm's part to become members of the CIF pensions scheme for purposes of this school contract.

MainHeading.P: My Department is now calling on the firm to indicate that it is in compliance with the standard clause referred to, and if it be found that the firm is in breach of this clause appropriate action will be taken in relation to this school project. Due note would be taken of the outcome of this investigation in relation to any further tenders which this firm might submit for other projects for which my Department may be seeking tenders.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - 50 Metre Olympic Swimming Pool.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when he will be in a position to provide a 50 metre Olympic swimming pool in Ireland; when the national sports centre will be established; if he will instruct the national sports centre committee to formally consider the question of the pool; if he will appoint a swimming representative to the committee; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: The committee appointed to examine the requirements of a national sports centre has been examining the needs of the entire range of indoor and outdoor sports, including swimming, over the past number of months. The committee will be presenting its report to me at an early date.

The timing of the establishment of a national sports centre and the question of the provision of a 50 metre swimming pool, should such provision be recommended by the committee, are matters which will be decided upon following consideration of the committee's report.

The members of the committee were appointed on the basis of their interest in and commitment to sport, their professional backgrounds and also having regard to their expertise to recommend the provision of facilities which would best serve the Irish community. The Deputy will appreciate that sports could not be represented individually on the committee.

asked the Minister for Labour the reason a person (details supplied) in Dublin 9 who was taken on as a dental technician by his father and who had been registered with Manpower, does not get the same allowance as other similar apprentices would in circumstances where they were taken on in that profession.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The person to whom the Deputy refers is unemployed at present and his parents have advised officials of my Department that they are seeking either employment for him or financial aid to enable his father employ him.
Neither the employment incentive scheme nor the work experience programme is applicable in respect of parents offering to employ or give work experience to their own children.
It might be possible for the parent to sponsor his son for an apprenticeship course in dental craftsmanship but I understand that this is not what the parent has in mind.

The National Manpower Service is making every effort to find employment for this person and I have requested that the appropriate placement officer in the NMS contact him to discuss and review his employment prospects.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - AnCO External Training.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will provide the following information regarding the £10.3 million allocation described in the AnCO report for the year ended 31 December 1984 as fees for external courses: (i) the names of the institutions to which these moneys were paid; (ii) the title of each of the courses pursued; (iii) the skill or qualification gained from each course; (iv) the duration of each course; (v) the cost of each of the courses and (vi) the criteria used by AnCO in selecting the particular institutions at which these courses were pursued.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: In the time available it has not been possible to gather all the information sought by the Deputy. I would propose therefore to deal only with (v) and (vi) of the question at this stage and to forward to the Deputy the outstanding information as soon as possible.
With regard to the question of the cost of each course it is not the policy of my Department to give details of amounts paid to particular companies or in respect of particular courses by AnCO.
The following, however, are the criteria applied by AnCO in engaging outside institutions, firms or consultants to provide external training.
—the competitiveness of the fees they charge;
—their particular training expertise especially as regards training the unemployed;
—the training facilities available to them;

MainHeading.P: —their performance and results in respect of previous training undertaken by them;
—their ability to operate in locations where training needs exist which cannot be met more efficiently or effectively from other AnCO programmes;
—their knowledge of industry's skill needs and their supporting contacts in industry;
—the need for a particular skill in the labour market which may not be readily available from within AnCO's other programmes.
Appropriate firms or consultants are selected on a tendering basis. Tendering documents in respect of each course give the following details:
(a) Resources — both physical and manpower,
(b) Course design,
(c) Cost of providing the course.
I should point out to the Deputy that I have recently instituted arrangements whereby the educational system will become more involved in the provision of external courses on behalf of AnCO.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the amount of money which was allocated each year to the employment incentive scheme for job creation in Dublin's inner city since the inception of the scheme; and the amount which was actually spent each year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: There are no budget allocations for particular regions or districts under the employment incentive scheme. The practice of successive Governments has generally been to provide whatever funds are necessary at the level of the State to operate the scheme on the basis of projected take-up by employers.

Statistics of participation are kept on a regional basis. The Dublin region which embraces counties Wicklow, Kildare, Meath and Dublin, including the Dublin inner city area, accounts for approximately 40 per cent of recruitment take-up under the scheme. In 1985 notified recruitments amounted to over 7,500 with approximately 3,000 recruitments in the Dublin region.
Statistics are not kept on a sub-regional basis.
